etymology.description: 喇叭 + 花 = trumpet-shaped flower (morning glory).
etymology.interpretation: Colloquial metaphor: the corolla looks like a horn, so it’s called a “trumpet flower,” referring to morning glories.

examples.chinese: 早上，院墙上的喇叭花开得正艳(早上，院牆上的喇叭花開得正豔)。
examples.pinyin: Zǎoshang, yuànqiáng shàng de lǎbahuā kāi de zhèng yàn.
examples.english: In the morning, the morning glories on the courtyard wall are in full bloom.

examples.chinese: 她把喇叭花编成小花环，挂在窗边(她把喇叭花編成小花環，掛在窗邊)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bǎ lǎbahuā biān chéng xiǎo huāhuán, guà zài chuāngbiān.
examples.english: She wove morning glories into a small garland and hung it by the window.

examples.chinese: 这种藤蔓喜欢阳光，喇叭花每天清晨准时开放(這種藤蔓喜歡陽光，喇叭花每天清晨準時開放)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè zhǒng téngmàn xǐhuān yángguāng, lǎbahuā měitiān qīngchén zhǔnshí kāifàng.
examples.english: This vine loves sunlight; the morning glory opens punctually every dawn.
